justification: The article notes that “actual self can be validly measured by implicit measures (e.g., response times on a me/not me implicit association task, or IAT)” indicating the IAT is used to assess one’s actual self-concept.

In contrasting measurement approaches, the authors explain that the “ideal self is typically indexed with explicit measures (e.g., direct report),” linking the construct of the ideal self to standard self-report questionnaires.
They state that priming high-level construal “increases self-regulation on a subsequent handgrip… task,” showing the handgrip task is employed as an operational measure of self-regulation capacity.

Reporting on an ego-depletion study, the paper says participants’ performance “on a cold-pressor task” indexed self-control after manipulation, demonstrating the cold-pressor as a behavioral measure of self-regulation.

The same construal-level research is described as improving self-regulation on “intertemporal choice tasks,” indicating that choosing between smaller-sooner versus larger-later rewards serves as a metric of self-regulation.
